FRESHMEN RECOMMEND
REGULATIONS FOR 1931
If the plans of the class of
1930 materialize, next year's
freshmen will wear black and
blue skull caps, in order to allow the freshmen to become
assimilated quickly. In spite
of the fact that the yearlings
recently won a debate on the
affirmative side of abolishing
regulations, they advocate regulations for next year's class.
The frosh have voiced their
opinion in a resolution presented to the Student Council,
recommending that the Council enforce the proposed rules
next year. No action has been
taken by the Council.

Dr. Mitchell, a well known
and popular professor, has
been connected with. the University since 1919. He is, at
the present time, instructing
undergraduates in two courses.

DR. IRA REMSEN
The death of Dr. Remsen, the second of the great men in the
history of Hopkins lost to the University within the span of a single week leaves a gap the consciousness of which will remain for
a long time, and one which can never be entirely filled. It could
not be otherwise with a man who has meant so much to Hopkins.
He had been connected with the University ever since its beginning, always in a distinguished capacity. As a member of the
famous original faculty he was both a brilliant chemist and an
inspiring professor; during his term as president he performed inestimable services; and for the past fifteen years, as President
Emeritus he continued to devote his interest and to lend the prestige of his name to the University he had served so long.
Although the students, taken as a group are perhaps unable to
share in the personal sorrow of those men of Hopkins who actually
knew Dr. Remsen, and who cherish and reverence his memory as
a man as well as a scholar; to them also his death means more than
we can adequately put into words.
He was a symbol, a link with the University's inspiring past.
The one tradition which all Hopkins' men hold dear is the thought
of those early days, of the little group of brilliant men who in so
short a time so firmly established the reputation of the infant university. It has meant a great deal to know that one of those men
still lived; that as recently as the Half Century Celebration he was
an interested participant.
Now, however, the founders, that group already revered as a
tradition, are at last but a memory. This break with the past,
happily so long deferred, although it was of course inevitable, is
none the less a shock. No matter to what heights the University
may rise, there has gone out from its life something which can
never he entirely replaced.

Frosh Need Restraint

H. Garland Hershey was the first
speaker for the sophomore team.
His argument was very well delivThe points which were
ered.
brought out related to the necessity
of regulations to the development
of the freshman himself. "The
freshman," Hershey said, "comes to
college feeling he is 'big.' In high
school he was petted and pampered and at His graduation he was
showered with gifts and made to
feel as if he had accomplished some
great feat. However, when he
comes to college he must think for
himself and the change must be immediate."
The rushing season of the fraternities, it was pointed out, makes
the freshman still more of an egotist and regulations are needed to
tone him down. Activities are an
essential part of a liberal education
and regulations make freshmen go
out. It is possible, he conceded, that
freshmen would go out for activities after a time; but the time
should not be wasted and regulations are needed to make it imme-

FRESHMEN RECOMMEND
REGULATIONS FOR 1931
If the plans of the class of
1930 materialize, next year's
freshmen will wear black and
blue skull caps, in order to allow the freshmen to become
assimilated quickly. In spite
of the fact that the yearlings
recently won a debate on the
affirmative side of abolishing
regulations, they advocate regulations for next year's class.
The frosh have voiced their
opinion in a resolution presented to the Student Council,
recommending that the Council enforce the proposed rules
next year. No action has been
taken by the Council.

DR. IRA REMSEN
The death of Dr. Remsen, the second of the great men in the
history of Hopkins lost to the University within the span of a single week leaves a gap the consciousness of which will remain for
a long time, and one which can never be entirely filled. It could
not be otherwise with a man who has meant so much to Hopkins.
He had been connected with the University ever since its beginning, always in a distinguished capacity. As a member of the
famous original faculty he was both a brilliant chemist and an
inspiring professor; during his term as president he performed inestimable services; and for the past fifteen years, as President
Emeritus he continued to devote his interest and to lend the prestige of his name to the University he had served so long.
Although the students, taken as a group are perhaps unable to
share in the personal sorrow of those men of Hopkins who actually
knew Dr. Remsen, and who cherish and reverence his memory as
a man as well as a scholar; to them also his death means more than
we can adequately put into words.
He was a symbol, a link with the University's inspiring past.
The one tradition which all Hopkins' men hold dear is the thought
of those early days, of the little group of brilliant men who in so
short a time so firmly established the reputation of the infant university. It has meant a great deal to know that one of those men
still lived; that as recently as the Half Century Celebration he was
an interested participant.
Now, however, the founders, that group already revered as a
tradition, are at last but a memory. This break with the past,
happily so long deferred, although it was of course inevitable, is
none the less a shock. No matter to what heights the University
may rise, there has gone out from its life something which can
never he entirely replaced.

Frosh Need Restraint

H. Garland Hershey was the first
speaker for the sophomore team.
His argument was very well delivThe points which were
ered.
brought out related to the necessity
of regulations to the development
of the freshman himself. "The
freshman," Hershey said, "comes to
college feeling he is 'big.' In high
school he was petted and pampered and at His graduation he was
showered with gifts and made to
feel as if he had accomplished some
great feat. However, when he
comes to college he must think for
himself and the change must be immediate."
The rushing season of the fraternities, it was pointed out, makes
the freshman still more of an egotist and regulations are needed to
tone him down. Activities are an
essential part of a liberal education
and regulations make freshmen go
out. It is possible, he conceded, that
freshmen would go out for activities after a time; but the time
should not be wasted and regulations are needed to make it imme-
